Title: Metaphor
References: ŠTULAJTEROVÁ, A., JESENSKÁ, P.: English Stylistics. 1. vyd. Banská Bystrica : Univerzita Mateja Bela, 2013. 114 s.
Content:
A metaphor is a figure of speech which makes an implicit, implied or hidden comparison between two objects, things or people without using words like or as.

The metaphorical word or phrase has to have a primary (dictionary) and contextual (figurative) meanings togeather.A metaphore cannot therefore exist without a context. Metaphors can be classified according to their degree of unexpectedness:

  1. genuine metaphors - unpredictable, original
  2. trite (dead) metaphors - commonly used in speech

examples:

  • It's raining men.
  • America is a melting pot.
  • The policeman let him go with a yellow card.
